title: Friday, 15th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
Maverick Ahoy hoy
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hello, hi, welcome, hey there, good morning.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Grouchmonkey Ahoj!
BE11:09am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's markets live with the markets and the live.

Soundbuy Morning
Markkus morning all...
Swedish Chef Good morning from the 76 bus
Manxish Morning all, Happy Friday
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all
in the dark yet again Morning all. Me, completely new to this so be gentle with me.
BE11:11am

We're a wee bit risk-off this morning. Dollar up, FTSE down, strategist types still on about ECB.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Dovish, so eur and bunds head lower on expectations that we're getting four Fed hikes to zero in Europe.

KimKongUn PSTG and CPB on fire lot of interest and calls buying past weeks..
Maverick VM CYBG deadline fast approaching :)
Tom Dalgleish @Dark, we are always gentle but the markets are not
BE11:15am

Let's hoof some strategy up, since it's a Friday.

PeterC Morning, anything on Indivior?
BE11:16am

Here's the ever-readable Kit Junkles at SocGen.

Grouchmonkey @KimKong would you be a holder, by any chance?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

The ECB got what it wanted (I think): A spectacularly dovish announcement of the end of the asset purchase programme in December. The Tour de force was to push back the timing of the first rate hike to H2.

BE11:16am

The timing of the first hike is surely flexible but for now, acknowledging the soft patch the euro zone economy entered in Q1 and has yet to exit, justified punting the rate hike into the long grass.

Tom Dalgleish Re RR, don't the markets like a good purge?
SupposeToBeWorking... @Maverick Just as the PRA has decided to comment that VM might be playing musical chairs a little too recklessly?
Blank canvas In the dark: it's very simple, just sit back and enjoy the show - sometimes it's like the Muppets, others like a Ted talk
alewis2005 morning,happy friday!
Flaneur @blank canvas - lol, good summation.
Shinshin Reading the employment, sales, house price, loan offers all feels like 11pm on the midnight crash clock, and yet we're nowhere near having a cushion of rates to cut to make a stimulus. Can't be that many assets left to QE either!
BE11:18am

There’s still every reason to fear further Italian turmoil over the summer, so we remain nervous about the near-term outlook for the Euro. Technically, 1.1450-1.1510 is the key
support line and psychologically, 1.15 is crucial. It’s also our forecast for where we will be in September, with a gradual rehabilitation thereafter. Europe needs stronger data to change the rate debate and a calmer Italian political backdrop to provide confidence that normalisation leads to a stronger currency.

Swedish Chef As a holder of RR delighted, as a frequent flyer...
11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@Blank canvas: how dare you suggest we're anything like a Ted talk.)

BornCynic Morning
Soundbuy @blank canvas - you forgot to add, no deviating off topic allowed....
alewis2005 @In the dark, we don't bite, much. BE does though
SupposeToBeWorking... @Blank canvas the RoTL or the RoTR?
BE11:19am

Strong data (again) in the US today continue to put upward pressure on the Fed’s forward guidance. Clients I meet in the US are less concerned about an inversion in the curve, or a move higher in rates in general, than some of those in, say, Brazil a week ago. But the case for being nervous of emerging markets, somewhat bearish of credit, and to allocate more cash towards Treasuries as they sell off, seems clear.

BornCynic Iceland sales up - question - is that a good or bad sign ?
Manxish @Sound - and close the window the moment someone mentions house prices
undefined
SoS @Swedish - yes I'm delighted with Rolls Royce too. Mind you will they deliver on promises?
Penny @BE Kingfisher - did you recently mention a research note on here? May have been by Citi.If so, could you poss provide link please?I think the jist was that its in permanent restructure mode, and can't really get any worse. tk you
Swedish Chef Mention a certain CEO and his alleged habits and you get zapped.
BornCynic For all the Waitrose shoppers out there, that is of course the frozen food store - not the country.
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Yeah, okay, let's head into stocks.

Flaneur @BornCynic - Im agnostic on 'good' or 'bad' - I'd read it as a sign that consumers are squeezed. Again.
in the dark yet again @Blank canvas: what, like Statler and Waldorf? A certain degree of cynicism is no bad thing.
BE11:21am

@KimKongUn, we tend not to like people talking in tickers. Are you talking US? Do you mean Campbell's Soup and Pure Storage?

BornCynic @Flaneur - squeezed out of Aldi / Lidl ............
Grouchmonkey Eh? To allocate more cash to Treasuries as they sell off"? Doesn't sound like a money making strategy to me.
BE11:22am

Because ....... um. We'll probably not be covering either of those in the short to mid term.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We can instead talk Indivior

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 401.16, down 93.34 (-18.88%), High: 435.00, Low: 372.80, Volume: 5.66m
Widnes wonders @Shinshin, I agree, even away from London where thinsg appear sluggish, regional growth is slowing. what can more QE bring us... eventually the Bank will be sending checks in the post to the people.. esp if Corbyn gets in. Viva la revolution!!
BE11:23am

The unsurprising news is that that FDA's approved Suboxone film.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

The more surprising news is that Dr Reddy's chosen to launch its generic Suboxone immediately

KimKongUn @be Yes Campbell and Pure storage, sorry for the ticker new to the chat.Campbell cheap here, Pure storage they just did a cash call
nichoman buying indivior on these patent sell offs tends to have worked out well
BE11:24am

Even though Indivior has an appeal to a patent judgement yet to resolve, meaning Dr Reddy's is running a chance of landing itself a damages claim.

Grouchmonkey I thought all the expectations on Indivior were based on the new monthly injection treatment, not Suboxone anyway?
Excel Developer I am pleased EUR USD
BE11:25am

The "at risk" thing might also mean that Indivior can go to the courts to stop Dr Reddy's launch plans, but that's far from certain.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

@Grouchmonkey --yes, indeed. Indivior's model's always been to reformulate its synthetic scag at approximately the same pace as the patents expire.

BE11:26am

(Did I type "patents" there? Yes, I did. Phew.)

BE11:27am

But generic Suboxone film arriving nine- to 12-months earlier isn't ideal for that gameplan.

Grouchmonkey haha vg. I should disclose that I am a (chastened) Indivior holder but don't plan to sell on the news.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Because it means Indivior needs a flawless launch of the one-a-day injection to keep cash coming in.

BE11:28am

Jefferies is very good here.

BE11:29am

INDV’s 2018 guidance had assumed “no material changes in market conditions in the US, chiefly that an "at risk" launch of a generic buprenorphine/naloxone film product will not take place”. If DRRD has sufficient inventory and launches
by July 1, assuming a 40% net price reduction in 2H’18E and generic film takes an 11% share in 2H, we estimate that EPS in 2018 could be impacted by as much as 50%. However, an authorized generic would soften the impact and every $10m of cost savings would compensate by 3%; hence we await further details from the company on the expected impact. To some extent we expect some to look through market near-term concerns as the impact in 2020 is much more muted given the market was largely anticipating Gx in 2019; Sublocade sentiment will therefore be key.

Tom Dalgleish Jardine Mathieson had nothing on INDV
#REF! This week I've mainly been watching board struggles at Tungsten and Stobart. In the latter a RNS curiously spoke of 'concerns' the old CEO is trying to take control. did a lawyer really insist they call it concerns rather than a fact?
11:30 am
BE11:30am

We should of course call it buprenorphine/naloxone film, not Suboxone. Because calling drugs by the actual names rather than their trademarks is just good practice.

BE11:31am

Sublocade ramp-up now more critical than ever: Our 630p SOTP values Suboxone
Film at 112p; note our downside case (mid-19 Gx) is 65p. Even assuming 50% of our
downside case valuation for Suboxone Film we can make an investment case due to
Sublocade; however if momentum is stalled on Sublocade roll-out and the value proposition becomes more challenging, it would be a greater concern on fundamentals, in our view.

Airborne Cigar @BE - ...and cheaper at the chemists
BE11:31am

And Citigroup.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Removing Suboxone film from our model but maintaining our Sublocade
forecast impacts our NPV by c.40p per share but we expect INDV to take steps to
modify the cost structure, as a sharp loss in revenues is likely to occur. We expect
Mylan to take steps to launch their generic and Alvogen to launch as soon as they
receive approval, making for a competitive market. Meanwhile, management has
been conservative about the launch of Sublocade from Feb-18, although reiterate
confidence in greater than $1bn (Citi $1.1bn) from this product. We expect an update at 2Q18 results on 25th July.

Dec69 - Skeptic @GrouchMonkey, I have an inclining that there's another FCA (False Claims Act) Case brewing against Individior (Speculation on my part having spoken to lawyers in the US). Its not without risk IMO
Grouchmonkey --trouble is opiod addicts can't actually SAY buprenorphine/naloxone film
BE11:32am

(@Airborne Cigar: exactly. I'm sure many ML readers are also recovering heroin addicts.)

undefined
Dec69 - Skeptic Opoid's is a whole new can of worms IMO
11:33 am
BE11:33am

(@Grouchmonkey: counterpoint: Will Self.)

DJ Greencore looking jittery today
BE11:34am

Sticking with drugs, BTG's lung collapsing thingmybob has been knocked back.

Tom Dalgleish Seriously, is opioid addiction here to stay hence worth intensive study?
Grouchmonkey @Dec69 not without risk, certainly, but the potential of Sublocade is considerable in the longer term if US courts start requiring addicts to take it, like antabuse for alcohol
BE11:35am

FDA advisory panel votes against, on a thin margin, and not unexpectedly.

A. M. @Tom Dalgleish: here to stay in what sense?
Tom Dalgleish @AM, worth studing INDV and the ilk
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Safety concerns override potential benefit. But we kinda knew that'd be the outcome after briefing papers earlier in the week criticised its long-term benefit and poor data from a crossover study.

Dec69 - Skeptic @GrouchMonkey, indeed a possibility, but 'conpulsory treatment orders (CTO's) appear to be difficult to finance and something REGS aren't wanting
BE11:37am

Still -- it does keep the pressure on BTG to find something to sell once its snake antivenom rolls off patent.

Waterloo BTG not in a great place. Snake bite competition, patent expiry a slow start to some home grown stuff. Another ST interview with the Dame
BE11:37am

And pipeline results have been disappointing for a while. Here's Numis.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

The FDA convened Advisory Committee meeting made a recommendation against
approving the PneumRx coils last night, which is already reflected in our forecasts
and valuation, but further impacts sentiment. Separately, Sirtex has rejected the
bid from Varian and is going with the higher offer from CDH Investment, which
implies a 7x EV/Sales valuation for a business that has been losing material share to
BTG's Interventional Oncology (TheraSphere) business in recent years. However,
with unrealistic mid-term operating leverage implied by company guidance and
consensus expectations, our 840p per share valuation increasingly requires a
longer term investment horizon.

FATDAZ @Tom dalgleish re opiate addiction tenure I Imagine fentanyl will be a deciding factor in that
BE11:40am

Therasphere are radioactive microbeads to target tumors. The idea here was that Varian would come in and buy Sirtex, meaning BTG would have a much bigger and better funded competitor.

Dec69 - Skeptic I have a question on Glencore, being an novice in anything legal, how can Glencore pay a sanctioned individual when their transaction base also includes dollars. The objective of sanctions I thought was, 'if you 'touch' any dollars' irrespective of other currencies, you had to comply? Any thoughts, as to me it seems odd, but what do I know.
BE11:40am

And a competitor that was able to cross-sell a whole load of oncology products, which BTG obviously can't.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Anyway. RBC as well, since we're here.

BE11:41am

PneumRx coil makes up 5% of our SoTP share price and,
whilst this is not the ‘end’ of the product (further development could help the product gain approval at a later date), we would not be surprises to see a negative
reaction in the share price today. Consensus has FY22E revenues of c£10m, which we think may be at risk.

undefined
alewis2005 @FATDAZ that's brutal
Forester I would love to have the full text of that Rosenblatt legal letter re Tinkler/Woodford/Stobart. So serious allegations I understand.
wayneJ I find the whole US opoid / opiate situation weird. I don't know if societies can have a personality but the crisis in the US is unprecedented. But there are also unscrupulous actors.
Dec69 - Skeptic What's the news there @Forester?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

(@Dec69: I'm not sure I understand. Gertler's being paid in euros specifically to avoid US sanctions.)

Waterloo BTG big hope (one of the few they actually own) for Varicose Veins has so far been a bit of a flop.
wayneJ Has BTG ever successfully got a drug / medical intervention to market on time and achieved its projected sales? Just asking...
nichoman Does Glencore resolving its African matters allow Ivan to move on to a Bunge deal?
BE11:45am

Okay, where were we? Rolls was mentioned earlier. I guess we should cover Rolls.

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 953.40, up 70.6 (+8.00%), High: 1,011, Low: 951.00, Volume: 10.96m
Waterloo With trade war games now starting in earnest. is this the high tide for stocks?
wayneJ Surely GLEN should have paid into an escrow account until such point as sanctions settled. Anything else still subjects to US sanctions.... even converting USD to EUR?
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Guiding for free cashflow of about £1.8bn .... some time. We don't know when, but sometime.

Badger @waterloo For those commodities/goods on the list perhaps?
wayneJ Re VM - the leaked FCA letter - surely reduces the bid premium CYBG pays? Indeed if CYBG walks the downside for VM is significant?
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, US sanctions I was of the understanding meant those transacting in dollars (as well as other currencies) had to comply. As GLEN is mostly $ dominated, the utilisation of € as payment could be argued as avoiding the sanctions? (In my thought process). Please note GLEN were sued and costs/compensation/claims where outlined in dollars, they have resolved the issue, by allegedly now not touching any US transactional base. Is that appropraite? I don't know. I personally look at it as a "FX transaction." as the roaylties are earnt in dollars but converted to €.
Forester According to Shareprophets who have copy of the letter from Stobart’s solicitors Rosenblatt sent to Tinkler "which discusses the damning allegations made against him in detail. What is most extraordinary is that he is alleged to have been working in conjunction with fund manager Neil Woodford on actions that would have benefitted Tinkler and Woodford’s funds massively, at the expense of everyone else"
SupposeToBeWorking... @DEC69 Well it's a use case for bitcoin ;)

Forester Allegations of course and only one side of a long running story
BE11:49am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

Dec69 - Skeptic @SupposeToBeWorking, don't get me started ha.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

New mid-term cashflow guidance is well above consensus, and
cash KPIs suggest a ruthless focus on optimising investment.
Questions will likely focus on whether new targets represent
the best of all possible worlds, but that should not detract
from the emerging benefits of increased focus and rigour.

BE11:49am

How to interpret the new cash flow targets? We highlighted yesterday that
additional cost saving targets imply a 2022e FCF target above £1.4bn vs our
current estimates, though we believe consensus may be higher. The new midterm
target implies an absolute FCF figure close to £2bn, and we interpret this as
applying to 2023-24 - clearly a material upgrade.

BE11:50am

What does this mean for the shares? Assuming Rolls-Royce delivers £1.9bn of
FCF in 2023-24 implies a stock trading on a 12% FCF yield. Given the long time
horizon, investors will apply a discount to this, in our view. Nonetheless we
believe today's stock valuation of 6-6.5% FCF yield on 2020e forecasts is a
reasonable benchmark for the long term, and would still represent a discount to
other engine manufacturers in the more favoured narrowbody segment.

wayneJ Surely the obvious is for Glen to buy a big property in the US through an anonymous corporation and then transfer it to Gertler....AML / KYC virtually non-existent on US property transactions....just saying

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Tesco 1Q was slightly ahead of expectations driven by Booker. The core
UK business and International were bang in line. There is no reference to
current market expectations in the release albeit management highlights to
be pleased with the momentum in the business and the initial progress of
the merger.

BE12:05pm

I mean, they just bought Booker and have done nothing with it. It's the same business. I'm not sure that counts as "initial progress".

BE12:05pm

They've not broken it yet. Well done.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

No commentary on current market expectations in the release, we think management reiterates comfort at the call. “Our growth plans are on track and we are pleased with the momentum in the
business. We remain well-placed to serve our customers better and deliver on our medium-term financial ambitions. We are delighted with initial progress on Booker, and are focused on delivering the synergy benefits that our merger brings.”

Dec69 - Skeptic Good Humour today @BE.
FATDAZ @Borncynic whil on safari driving up a steeply inclined dirt track with 1000 ft + drop on the right hand side our guid / drive took s hands of the wheel and them sat on the door of our landcruiser chatting as the car drove itself most unnerving
wayneJ In the VC / startup world there is the ugly phrase - 'acqui-hire' - ie do an acquisition to hire someone - am wondering if we should think of Tesco buying Booker in that way?

And Barclays.

wayneJ I note a previous Booker CEO went on to run M&S IIRC

wayneJ Or genuine value in the CEO of Booker....
BE12:07pm

Tesco released its 1Q trading statement this morning. LFL sales growth of +14.3% from newly-acquired Booker will likely attract much attention but we focus first on the core Tesco UK/Ireland business. UK LFL sales growth of +2.1% was modestly ahead of the BBG-collected consensus of +1.9%. To have slowed down only slightly from 2H17/18 (+2.3%) is a good achievement given lower levels of inflation in the market, tougher comps and generally unhelpful weather in the quarter. Tesco highlights the progress with its own label re-launch (2,850 products completed out of the greater than 10,000 planned) and we note the additional price investment made at the end of 1Q. Although the statement says nothing on the important topics of profitability and cash generation, we believe that if current momentum can be maintained then a strong 1H should result in October.

Soundbuy Beer Day Britain today, cheers all and Bon w/end...............
